awd_titl_txt: Perceptual and Mnemonic Differences Across Cultures
awd_abstract_narration:
Does cultural background impact how people perceive the visual world and what they remember? Many assume that psychological processes are universal and not affected by native country or culture. But recently there has been increased appreciation of the ways in which an individual?s background can impact perceptual or memory processes. Prior work on cultural differences has largely considered memory and visual perception as separate processes and most of the work on visual processes has been restricted to evaluating face perception. The current project examines whether cultures differ in the visual features they preferentially perceive: Do they tend to perceive global, overall shape or fine detail? Does culture affect how quickly each type of visual information is processed or whether it dominates conscious experience? Does any difference in perception affect later memory for scenes? These are issues of global importance and will contribute to the development of a globally-minded workforce by exposing students and trainees to cross-cultural research. The investigators will also engage in outreach activities at a diverse local high school. Participating in these outreach activities will also train members of the team in effective scientific outreach and communication.

Four experiments will investigate cultural differences in 1) the relative dominance of high versus low spatial frequency information in vision, for stable percepts as well as those that compete dynamically for dominance, 2) brain markers of early attention processes versus markers of expectation or salience, using electroencephalography (EEG), 3) short-term memory, in comparison with perceptual judgments, and 4) measures of sensitivity (i.e., ability to accurately distinguish different types of information) versus response bias (i.e., a tendency to respond in a particular way). Extant models of visual perception and memory were predominantly developed based on the study of "WEIRD" subjects (Western, educated, and from industrialized, rich, and democratic countries). By systematically comparing across cultures, this research project will increase understanding of the interplay of culture, perception, and memory processes in our species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In terms of intellectual merit, this project investigated how cultural background influences thinking and judgments, focused on two distinct aspects of culture. The first line of research asked how people from different national backgrounds (i.e., United States and East Asian countries such as China) differed in perceiving basic information. These experiments focused on comparing responses to low and high spatial frequency visual information, which corresponds to global, large shape information and fine details. Past research suggested that East Asians tend to use global, low-spatial frequency information whereas Americans tend to use fine, high spatial frequency information when looking at faces. In our experiments, we used basic stimuli, such as alternating patches of black and white that differed in thickness, or the distance of the alternation between black and white. We did not find evidence that cultures differed in perceiving such basic stimuli, using behavioral or brain measures. These tests included comparing perceptual and attentional brain responses to seeing patches of black and white lines with different thickness; both cultural groups exhibited larger responses to low than high spatial frequency information. Another experiment presented each eye with either low or high spatial frequency information so that the visual information competed. The cultural groups did not differ on which type of information dominated their perception. In addition, we extended tests of cultural differences in perception to short-term memory, memory that lasts on the order of seconds. Memory declined in both cultural groups as less high spatial frequency information was present in the pictures, but the cultural groups did not differ on memory performance. Our takeaway from this research is that promising future directions are to explore culture’s influence on the interplay between perception, attention, and memory, and that cultural differences may emerge more in higher-level than lower-level cognitive processes.

The other way we investigated culture is by testing how the tightness or looseness of social norms affected behaviors and attitudes relevant to the COVID-19 pandemic at its outset (Spring 2020). This line of research was based on prior research showing how countries and even US states differ on tightness-looseness. In our survey-based study, the state-level effects (comparing US states that were high and low on tightness, based on archival, historical data) were minimal. However, results based on how individuals self-reported their perception of the tightness of their state indicated that people who rated their state as higher on tightness reported engaging in more mask wearing and handwashing during COVID-19. They also endorsed more future policy changes (e.g., quarantines, vaccines) to contain the pandemic, and reported feeling more responsibility for one’s life. They also expressed stronger negative attitudes toward Asians, an outgroup sometimes seen as associated with the pandemic. The effects of tightness were separate from the effects of political attitudes or other demographic factors. Thus, the results suggested that perceptions of state social norms were associated to some degree with public health behaviors and attitudes towards marginalized groups.

In terms of broader impacts, a number of students, including undergraduates, contributed to the research. This experience helped them to develop skills to become independent researchers and gain admission to PhD programs through their credentials. Some funding was dedicated to support a summer internship for a student researcher from a background underrepresented in the sciences. We also contributed to organizing the ongoing Culture and Cognition pre-conference with a goal of bringing together researchers and trainees to strengthen the community interested in the study of culture. In addition, before the COVID-19 pandemic, we participated in a community outreach event at a local high school. In this event, students from the lab shared stories about their path into science, and demonstrated experimental tasks with the students.

In summary, the major takeaways of the research are:

- During the COVID-19 pandemic, people who perceived their state as having tight social norms, with strong laws and punishment for violating them, reported engaging in more public health behaviors, such as mask wearing and handwashing to help stop the spread of COVID-19. Although there was much discussion that political attitudes could shape behaviors and attitudes during the pandemic, we identify a distinct factor that is associated with behaviors and attitudes.

- Despite findings that cultural groups can differ in their use of broad, global information versus fine-grained details, perception of basic, carefully-controlled visual information does not seem to differ across cultures. It may be necessary for information to compete in the demands placed on attention or memory in order for cultural differences to emerge in performance.
